Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Atomic Force Microscope for Interdisciplinary Nanoscience Research and Education at Fordham University
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities Programs, Professor Ipsita Banerjee from Fordham University and colleagues John McMahon, Stephen Holler, Petr Shibayev and Christopher Koenigsmann have acquired a high resolution atomic force microscope (AFM). An AFM, unlike an optical microscope, does not use light to create an image. An AFM employs a microscopic probe (needle-like device) that passes over a surface. As the probe moves across the surface it generates electrical signals which describe the properties of the surface (hardness, roughness, cracks, wettability, elasticity, etc.). In this way, it produces an image of the surface. This information is important for visually characterizing the surface. AFM is useful for understanding why a chemical reaction may occur on the surface, or why the surface is unreactive (inert). In general, an AFM has three major abilities: force measurement, imaging, and manipulation. An AFM is an important tool in the development of novel materials for fuel cell catalysis, enhanced solar panels, and for very small nanoparticle sensors, all of which rely on specific surface properties and morphology. AFM is used to characterize biological tissue, viruses and drug delivery materials. The instrument is employed in undergraduate research projects training these students in the use of this technique and preparing them for future technological careers in the workplace and advanced degrees in science, engineering and medical fields.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying tissue scaffolds, protein dynamics and viral nanoparticles, (b) studying microcavity photonics, (c) analyzing nanomaterials for catalysis and fuel cells, (d) examining the role of iodine in the photocatalysis of oxygen reduction at a silver/silver iodide (Ag/AgI) fuel cell cathode and (e) studying stimuli-responsive liquid crystals and liquid crystalline polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded the purchase of a Bruker MultiMode 8 Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) with Electrochemistry STM Converter that is housed in the Chemistry Department at Fordham University (Rose Hill campus) and is shared by faculty and students from the Chemistry, Physics and Biology departments. Several undergraduate students from these STEM departments have been trained for the use of the instrument and regularly use the facilities for their faculty mentored research projects.

The AFM has facilitated research in a wide range of projects ranging from bioengineering (characterization of synthetic tissue scaffolds; drug delivery vehicles for tumor targeting), environmental applications for detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in gaseous mixtures, and development of novel nanoscale catalysts. Fordham University is located in the Bronx, in New York City. In addition to faculty and students from Fordham and the vicinity, selected high school students from the NYC area who are mentored by our faculty have also been trained on the instrument. A few of those highschool students have gone on to participate in national and regional science competitions and have received top honors.

During the award period, faculty members and their students have published over ten papers, including a feature article, and several students and faculty have presented their work at various international, national and regional conferences. More data is currently being acquired that have yet to be published. Highlights include developing novel tissue engineering scaffolds for bone and neural tissue engineering, and a new peptide based nanovehicle that successfully targeted breast and ovarian tumor cells. Novel nanoscale catalysts comprised of ruthenium oxide nanowires were developed. For the first time, by using AFM microscopy, the reconstruction of chiral surfaces of oligomeric compounds and their mixtures with chiral and non-chiral low molar mass liquid crystals were observed upon interactions with volatile organic compounds. Forthcoming publications from this grant include exploration of ionic liquid interactions with peptides as well as development of novel liquid crystals for environmental applications.

This grant also resulted in training of several faculty members and students in the use of the AFM. Several of those students have published papers resulting from their work, and are now pursuing higher degrees at top universities in the country and have enormously benefited from the training under this grant. The results of their work have also been shared widely, which allows extensive dissemination of their research to the general public. The AFM has also been used in some of the teaching laboratory experiments.
